RETAINING WALLS
Every retaining wall has backfill soils that are placed behind and sometimes below the wall. It is quite common for some settling to take place in these areas. If you inspect the wall each spring for any unusual or excessive settling, you can save your wall from a potentially large problem.
Once an area behind the wall begins to settle, water continues to make that area deeper and bigger. If a low spot is neglected behind a wall, during each rain water collects at that spot and work its way down. This continues to build more in more in pressure against the wall. If the wall wasn’t designed or engineered to hold up the added weight, a blow-out could occur resulting in thousands of dollars in damage.

Regularly inspect your retaining wall. Look for low spots and areas that have settled. Pull back the landscaping and add enough new fill if needed.

From time to time you may see weeds growing in the face of stone, brick, block or timbered walls. Allowed to stay in place, one weed can multiply into a garden all by itself. This too can have negative effects on the structural integrity of the wall. Pull weeds that finds their way into the wall. If pulling weeds isn’t your idea of a great weekend, spray the wall just like the lawn for weed control / killer.
All retaining walls should be designed and built to route water around or over the wall face, additional controls can be established using drainage ports near the bottom of the wall or a continuous drain.
See also: Erosion
